<target_code>
Here is the code of send_all:
```c
static size_t
send_all (MHD_socket sock, const unsigned char *buf, size_t len)
{
  ssize_t ret;
  size_t off;

  for (off = 0; off < len; off += (size_t) ret)
  {
#if ! defined(_WIN32) || defined(__CYGWIN__)
    ret = send (sock, (const void *) &buf[off], len - off, 0);
#else  /* Native W32 */
    ret = send (sock, (const void *) &buf[off], (int) (len - off), 0);
#endif /* Native W32 */
    if (0 > ret)
    {
      if (EAGAIN == errno)
      {
        ret = 0;
        continue;
      }
      break;
    }
    if (0 == ret)
    {
      break;
    }
  }
  return off;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No suspicious fragments found w.r.t. MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13. Analysis: the only pointer in the function is the parameter 'const unsigned char *buf', which is already const‑qualified as required. The address expression '&buf[off]' (or equivalently 'buf + off') has type 'const unsigned char *' and is cast to 'const void *' when passed to send; that cast preserves const qualification and does not drop const. There are no local non‑const pointer variables, no casts that remove const, and no function calls here that accept a non‑const pointer type requiring a const removal. Therefore there are no code fragments in this function that need investigation for Rule 8.13.
